questions.question: Question 1: The anorectal angle is formed by which muscle?
questions.explanation:
The puborectalis muscle encircles the posterior and lateral aspects of the anorectal junction, 
creating the anorectal angle. At rest, the anorectal angle is held at 90 - 100°. This becomes more acute (70 - 90°) during 
squeezing due to the contraction and shortening of the puborectalis muscle. This brings the 600 
Sold by @itachibot anorectal junction higher and nearer to the pubic symphysis. During straining and defecation, the anorectal angle becomes more obtuse (110 - 180°) due to 
relaxation of the puborectalis muscle. The anorectal ring is formed by the fusion of: • Puborectalis • Deep external anal sphincter • Internal anal sphincter Note: Anismus, is caused by a failure of the puborectalis and external anal sphincter to relax 
during defecation straining. This results in a failure of the anorectal angle to straighten during 
defecation.

questions.question: Question 2: What is the length of the adult rectum?
questions.explanation:
The adult rectum is approximately 12–18 cm in length and is conventionally divided into three 
equal parts - the upper, middle and lower 1/3rd.

questions.question:
Question 3: Which fascial layer should be dissected to separate the rectum from the coccyx while 
operating on a patient with rectal adenocarcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Waldeyer's fascia separates the rectum from the coccyx. The lower third of the rectum is separated by the following: • from the prostate or vagina anteriorly - by Denonvilliers’ fascia • from the coccyx and lower two sacral vertebrae- by Waldeyer’s fascia Waldeyer's fascia originates at the S2 to S4 level from the presacral parietal fascia and fuses with 
the rectal visceral fascia at the posterior aspect of the rectum. It divides the retrorectal space into 601 
Sold by @itachibot superior and inferior compartments. Identification and preservation of the presacral fascia play an important role in preventing 
complications and reducing local recurrences of rectal cancer.

questions.question:
Question 5: The instrument shown below will be least useful for examining patients with which of the 
following conditions?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows a proctoscope. It is not used for examining patients with anal fissures. Due to pain, digital rectal examination and anoscopy are not performed immediately in an acute 
anal fissure. It is reserved for later when the symptoms resolve or the patient is in the operating 
room. 602 
Sold by @itachibot Proctoscopy is indicated in patients with the following: • Rectal bleeding • Change in bowel habit, especially recurring attacks of diarrhea • Pain or difficulty in defecation • Lesions around the anal opening - abscesses, fistulae, discharge, ulcers, external hemorrhoids • Rectal prolapse.

questions.question:
Question 6: An anxious mother rushed her 2-year-old child to the casualty when she noticed a 
red-coloured mass protruding from his anus. The mother gave a history of the child straining 
while passing stools for the past 2 weeks. There was no abdominal tenderness, and on local 
examination, a 6 cm mass with circumferential folds and slight edema was noted. How will 
you manage this child?
questions.explanation:
The given history and examination finding is suggestive of rectal prolapse. In children, the 
prolapse is usually mucosal and should be treated conservatively. Rectal prolapse occurs when a mucosal or full-thickness layer of rectal tissue protrudes through 
the anal orifice. Conservative treatment for rectal prolapse in children is to control: • Diarrhea • Worm infestation • Malnutrition Sclerotherapy can also be used.

questions.question:
Question 7: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the management of patients with 
rectal prolapse?

options.a: Surgery is necessary for full-thickness rectal prolapse
options.b: Delorme’s operation is done via the perineal approach
options.c: Ripstein's procedure is done via abdominal approach
options.d: Abdominal rectopexy is often preferred in high risk individuals

questions.explanation:
The perineal approach is often preferred in patients with high operative risk and limited life 
expectancy, i.e. in the elderly. It is associated with less morbidity but has a higher recurrence 
rate. Abdominal approaches (laparoscopic, robotic, or open) are preferred for younger patients, 
particularly those with constipation or associated pelvic floor disorders. Perineal procedures: • Delorme's mucosectomy- involves mucosal stripping and muscle plication of the rectal prolapse 
using interrupted sutures. It is performed externally under regional or general anaesthesia. • Thiersch's encirclement- a steel wire, or Silastic or nylon tape, is placed around the anal canal. 
Largely obsolete now due to problems with chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed 
defaecation • Altemeier rectosigmoidectomy- involves removal of the prolapsed rectum and associated 
sigmoid colon, followed by which a coloanal anastomosis is created. It is often complicated by 
poor bowel control with faecal soiling secondary to the loss of rectal reservoir. Abdominal procedures: • Suture rectopexy 603 
Sold by @itachibot • Mesh rectopexy • Posterior (Well’s and lvalon’s) • Anterior (Ripstein’s) • Lateral (Orr-Loygue) • Ventral • Resection Rectopexy (Frykman–Goldberg) The principle of all abdominal operations for rectal prolapse is to fix the rectum in its normal 
anatomical position.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following is not true regarding solitary rectal ulcers?

options.a: Commonly seen on the posterior wall
options.b: Rectal bleeding Is a common presentation
options.d: Colonoscopy with biopsy is the investigation of choice

questions.explanation:
A solitary rectal ulcer is usually located on the anterior rectal wall, 6-8 cm from the anal verge. It commonly presents with rectal bleeding in the setting of chronic straining or 
constipation. Histology reveals a thick layer of fibrosis obliterating the lamina propria and a 
central fibrinous exudate. Colonoscopy with biopsy is the investigation of choice for diagnostic evaluation, while 
defecography (proctography) is the radiologic procedure of choice. Stapled trans-anal rectal resection(STARR procedure) is the management of choice.

questions.question:
Question 9: What is the radiological procedure of choice in patients suspected to have a solitary rectal 
ulcer?
questions.explanation:
Defecography (proctography) is the radiologic procedure of choice for diagnostic evaluation in 
solitary rectal ulcer syndrome (SRUS). Some common findings include: • Full-thickness rectal prolapse 604 
Sold by @itachibot • Internal prolapse • Paradoxical puborectalis syndrome • Thickened rectal folds Defecography evaluates in real-time the morphology of the rectum and anal canal in a physiologic 
setting by injection of a thick barium paste into the rectum and its subsequent evacuation. It is primarily performed for workup of patients with: • Longstanding constipation • Unexplained anal or rectal pain • Residual sensation after defecation • Suspected prolapse.

questions.question: Question 10: What is the earliest manifestation in patients with rectal carcinoma?
questions.explanation: Per-rectal bleeding is the earliest and most common symptom of rectal carcinoma. Other symptoms of rectal carcinoma include: • Mucus drainage • Tenesmus • Early morning diarrhoea • Pain • Weight loss.

questions.question:
Question 12: An elderly man with per-rectal bleeding is suspected to have rectal carcinoma. Which of the 
following is false regarding this condition?

options.a: Majority of the cancers are sporadic
options.b: Dose of radiation used for this tumor is 45 Gy
options.c: Dissection lateral to the endopelvic fascia investing the mesorectum causes local recurrence
options.d: Precise location of the tumor is determined with rigid proctosigmoidoscopy

questions.explanation:
Dissection medial (not lateral) to the endopelvic fascia investing the mesorectum causes local 
recurrence. Dissection lateral to the avascular anatomic space, risks injury to the mixed autonomic nerves, 
causing impotence in men and bladder dysfunction in men and women. Transmesorectal resection involves complete removal of the lymph node bearing mesorectum 
along with its intact enveloping fascia. It is a curative resection of rectal tumours of the middle 
and lower thirds of the rectum, either as part of Low Anterior Resection (LAR) or 
Abdominoperineal Resection (APR). 606 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: The majority of colorectal cancers are sporadic. Approximately 5% of all colorectal 
cancers are attributed to familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and Lynch syndrome (hereditary 
non-polyposis colorectal cancer). Option B: The large bowel can tolerate delivered radiation doses of up to 6000 cGy. However, 
a lower dose of 45 Gy is recommended for colorectal tumours. High levels of radiation targeted at 
colon tumours would include the small bowel in the treatment field. This results in complications 
such as radiation enteritis. Option D: The precise location of the rectal tumour is determined using rigid 
proctosigmoidoscope or flexible sigmoidoscopy and biopsy. The other investigations used in rectal 
cancer include: • Digital rectal examination - for assessing the depth of penetration • Endorectal ultrasound or MRI - provides an accurate assessment of the extent of invasion of the 
bowel wall • MRI with an endorectal coil - is the investigation of choice to assess the 'T' and 'N' stages • CECT - for evaluation of metastasis.

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following statements is false regarding rectal carcinoma?

options.a: Hartmann’s operation is done in elderly debilitated patients
options.b: Adenocarcinoma is a rare variant of rectal carcinoma
options.c: Early morning spurious diarrhoea and tenesmus can occur
options.d: Growth confined to the rectal mucosa is stage A of modified Duke’s staging

questions.explanation:
Adenocarcinoma is the most common variant of rectal carcinoma. Colorectal cancer is: • The second most common malignancy globally • The second most common cancer in women • The third most common cancer in men • The fourth most common cause of death due to cancer. Symptoms of rectal carcinoma include: • Painless bleeding - earliest and most common • Alteration of bowel habits - change in frequency and consistency of the stool • Tenesmus - unable to pass a motion even when there is the sensation of needing to evacuate the 
bowel. It is suggestive of a tumor of the lower half of the rectum • Early morning bloody diarrhea (option C) - passage of blood and mucus in addition to feces. Pain 
and weight loss are usually late symptoms Abdominal examination and digital rectal examination are used for the primary evaluation. Rigid 
sigmoidoscopy is performed to obtain a biopsy. A synchronous tumor (primary tumor with a 
different origin than the one currently investigated) is excluded by performing a colonoscopy. Modified Duke’s classification: 607

permanent colostomy. • Hartmann’s operation (option A) is preferred in old and frail patients due to poor anal sphincter 
and postoperative incontinence.

questions.question:
Question 14: In patients with rectal carcinoma, what is the investigation of choice for assessment of 
perirectal nodes and the depth of penetration?
questions.explanation:
608 
Sold by @itachibot Endorectal-coil magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the best modality for predicting lymph 
node invasion and overall local staging. It can identify involved perirectal nodes on the basis of characteristics other than size. It can also 
identify foci at sites not only within the mesorectum but also outside the mesorectal fascia, such 
as pelvic sidewalls, and can identify the depth of penetration.

questions.question:
Question 15: Which of the following is the most common site of blood-borne metastasis in patients with 
rectal carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
The principal sites for blood-borne metastases in rectal carcinoma are 
the liver > lungs > adrenals.

questions.question:
Question 17: A patient with rectal carcinoma is posted under your unit for surgery. Which of the following 
correctly describes the margins of clearance that will be required in this surgery?
questions.explanation:
The margins of clearance required for the surgery of rectal carcinoma is: • Proximal - 5 cm 611 
Sold by @itachibot • Distal - 2 cm • Radial- 5 cm (for the removal of mesorectal nodes) Historically, a 5 cm clearance margin was the common practice. However, the 5 cm rule has been 
replaced by the 2 cm rule to help preserve the anal sphincters. When a negative distal margin can be achieved by sparing the sphincter, a sphincter sparing 
surgery such as low anterior resection (LAR) is performed. If it is not possible to achieve a negative distal margin and spare the sphincter (when the tumour 
is within 5cm of anal verge), abdominal perineal resection (APR) is done. APR/LAR must include total mesorectal excision (TME) to ensure margin clearance and lymph 
node retrieval.

questions.question:
Question 18: 598 
Sold by @itachibot A 55-year-old man presents to the clinic with a history of intermittent blood in stools for the 
past 3 months. After a detailed workup, he is diagnosed with rectal adenocarcinoma which is 
located 8 cm from the anal verge. There is no nodal or distant metastasis. Which of the 
following surgeries would you prefer in managing this patient?
questions.explanation:
Low anterior resection (LAR) is the preferred surgery in rectal carcinoma which is located at least 
5 - 5.5 cm away from the anal verge. It is not performed: • If adequate margin could not be achieved even after preoperative chemoradiotherapy • If the sphincters have to be sacrificed to achieve an adequate margin • In patients who cannot tolerate low anastomosis. In such cases, where anterior resection cannot be performed in distal rectal cancers, 
abdominoperineal resection (APR) is done. APR/LAR must include total mesorectal excision (TME) to ensure margin clearance and lymph 
node retrieval.

questions.question:
Question 19: Transanal local excision can be done in rectal carcinoma patients with all of the following 
tumour features except  
.

options.a: Tumor within 8 cm of the anal verge
options.d: T2 tumor without lymph node involvement

questions.explanation:
T2 rectal cancers are managed by transabdominal resection. Transanal local excision is recommended for selected T1, N0 early-stage cancers which fulfill the 
following criteria: • Small (<3 cm), well- to moderately-differentiated tumors • Tumors within 8 cm of the anal verge • Tumors limited to <30% of the rectal circumference • Tumors with no evidence of nodal involvement • Full-thickness excision must be feasible. 612 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 20: Which of the following chemotherapy regimens is used for treating patients with rectal 
carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
5-Fluorouracil-based regimens with leucovorin and oxaliplatin (FOLFOX) reduce recurrence and 
improve survival in patients with colorectal carcinoma. Irinotecan (FOLFIRI regimen) is also used as a second-line chemotherapy agent. Adjuvant 
chemotherapy is routinely recommended in patients with lymph node involvement. Option B: ABVD regimen is used for Hodgkin's lymphoma. Option C: RCHOP regimen is used for B-cell Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Option D: MVAC regimen is used for advanced bladder carcinoma.

questions.question:
Question 21: An 80-year-old man with rectal carcinoma presented with features of intestinal obstruction. 
How will you manage this patient?
questions.explanation:
Hartmann’s operation is an excellent procedure in an elderly, frail patient in whom there is 
concern about anal sphincter function or the viability of an anastomosis. Through an abdominal incision, the rectum is excised, the rectal stump is stapled closed and the 
proximal colon exteriorized as a permanent end colostomy. Note: Endoluminal stenting is being increasingly used in patients with obstructing carcinomas. It 
can be either used as a palliative procedure or to relieve the obstruction. Only rectosigmoid and 
upper rectal tumours are suitable for stenting because stent impingement on the anorectum in 
low cancers can result in tenesmus. 613 
Sold by @itachibot Anus and Anal Canal
